name: Location of Natarbora Refinery and Petrochemical Complex
evidence: The Natarbora Refinery and Petrochemical Complex is a planned industrial facility to be located in Natarbora, Timor Leste

name: Distance from Beaço
evidence: The complex is to be about 60 km west of Beaço on Timor-Leste's south coast

name: Distance from Dili
evidence: The complex is to be about 75 km southeast of Dili

name: Components of the Natarbora Complex
value_raw: Marine Facility/Seaport, Refinery and Petrochemical Complex, LNG Plant
evidence: The Natarbora Refinery and Petrochemical Complex, designed as a self-sustainable integrated facility, is part of a larger complex comprising three main areas: Marine Facility/Seaport, Refinery and Petrochemical Complex, LNG Plant with supplementary gas processing.

name: Assessment Coverage
value_raw: Preliminary ESIA does not cover LNG or Seaport
evidence: Although this Preliminary ESIA does not cover the LNG or Seaport, it is important to recognize that assessing risks and impacts is challenging without considering these closely linked facilities

name: Objectives of Preliminary ESIA
evidence: This Preliminary Environmental and Socioeconomic Impact Assessment is compiled to evaluate the environmental and social implications of the proposed Natarbora Refinery and Petrochemical Complex.

name: Initial production capacity
evidence: "an initial production capacity based on a feedstock input of 30,000 barrels per day (bpd)"

name: Stage 2 production capacity
evidence: "followed by expansion to 60,000 bpd in Stage 2"

name: Stage 3 production capacity
evidence: "ultimately reaching 100,000 bpd in Stage 3"

name: Capacity units
evidence: "capacity units are in thousand barrels per stream day (kBPSD) and tonnes per day (TPD)"

name: Crude Distillation Capacity
evidence: Primary unit used to separate crude oil through heating into different fractions or cuts like naphtha, kerosene, diesel, and residual oils.

name: Naphtha Hydrotreater Capacity
evidence: Removes impurities such as sulfur, nitrogen, and metals from naphtha feedstocks to produce cleaner products and meet environmental standards.

name: Diesel Hydrotreater Capacity
evidence: Removes impurities such as sulfur, nitrogen, and metals from diesel feedstocks to produce cleaner products and meet environmental standards.

name: Semi Regenerative Reformer Capacity
evidence: Converts naphtha into high-octane reformate, rich in aromatics and hydrogen, through catalytic reforming, with periodic catalyst regeneration to maintain efficiency and yield.

name: Light Naphtha Isomerization Capacity
evidence: Converts straight-chain hydrocarbons into branched-chain hydrocarbons, to increase the octane number of fuels without altering molecular weight significantly.

name: Sulfur Recovery Capacity
evidence: Converts hydrogen sulfide and other sulfur compounds from gas streams into elemental sulfur, helping to reduce sulfur emissions and comply with environmental regulations.

name: LPG Sweetening Capacity
evidence: Removes or neutralizes mercaptans and other sulfur compounds from Liquefied Petroleum Gas, enhancing its odor and meeting product quality specifications.

name: Kerosene Sweetening Capacity
evidence: Optional

name: Petrochemical Processing Facility Capacity
value_raw: Listed in KTA or thousand tonnes per year
evidence: The petrochemical processing facility capacity are listed below in KTA or thousand tonnes per year.

name: Steam Cracker Capacity
evidence: Steam Cracker 1000 KTA

name: Propane Dehydrogenation (PDH) Capacity
evidence: Propane Dehydrogenation (PDH) 500 KTA

name: High Density Polyethylene (HDPE) / Linear Low-Density Polyethylene (LLDPE) Capacity
evidence: High Density Polyethylene (HDPE) / Linear Low-Density Polyethylene (LLDPE) 2x 500 KTA

name: Low Density Polyethylene (LDPE) Capacity
evidence: Low Density Polyethylene (LDPE) 400 KTA

name: Polypropylene (PP) Capacity
evidence: Polypropylene (PP) 500 KTA

evidence: C4SHU Selective Hydrogenation Unit 240 KTA

name: MTBE Capacity
evidence: MTBE 64 KTA

name: Butene-1 Capacity
evidence: Butene-1 59 KTA

evidence: C4/C5 THUTotal Hydrogenation Unit 175 KTA

name: Pygas Hydrotreating Unit (PGHU) Capacity
evidence: Pygas Hydrotreating Unit (PGHU) 116 KTA

name: C6-C9 Hydrodealkylation Unit (HDA) Capacity
evidence: C6-C9 Hydrodealkylation Unit (HDA) 73 KTA

name: Benzene Extraction Unit (BEU) Capacity
evidence: Benzene Extraction Unit (BEU) 56 KTA

name: Maximum Net Energy Consumption
evidence: The maximum case net energy consumption is estimated to be 3,032,226 Gigacalories per year (Gcal/yr).

name: Makeup Water Requirement
evidence: Approximately 1,000 tonnes per hour (TPH) of makeup water will be required to operate the refinery-petrochemical facilities.

name: Freshwater Consumption
evidence: If the facilities operate continuously for a total 8,000 hours in a year, that represents 8 million cubic meters of freshwater consumption.

name: Sea Water Cooling System Duty Load
evidence: The sea water cooling system duty load is 620 MW.

name: Sea Water Requirement
evidence: The sea water cooling system duty load is assumed as requiring up to 107,000 cubic meters per hour (m3/hr).

name: Maximum Sea Water Temperature Rise
evidence: with a maximum sea water temperature rise of 5°C within the mixing zone.

name: Air pollutants
value_raw: sulfur oxides (SOx/SO₂), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds (VOCs), particulate matter (PM), carbon dioxide (CO₂), carbon monoxide (CO)
evidence: Air Emissions include pollutants such as sulfur oxides (SOx/SO₂), nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and particulate matter (PM).

name: Maximum daytime sound level
evidence: Typically, this is 70 dB(A) Leq (i.e., 70 dB(A) equivalent continuous sound level).

name: Greenhouse gas emissions
evidence: Releases of carbon dioxide (CO₂) and methane (CH₄) from the complex, in tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO₂-Eq), are estimated at 2.072 million tonnes per year (TPY).

name: Refinery emissions
evidence: Refinery 300, 000 TPY.

name: Petrochemicals emissions
evidence: Petrochemicals 1,772,000 TPY.

name: Distance from Aubeon Village
evidence: An initial site assessment reveals that the refinery will be located approximately one kilometer from Aubeon Village.

name: Waste management
evidence: Contaminated soil and absorbent materials will be handled as hazardous waste.

name: Effluent treatment
evidence: All wastewaters contaminated with hydrocarbons, metals, and other elements and compounds, prior to discharge into surface water bodies, will be treated in an industrial wastewater treatment plant (IWTP) designed to international standards.

name: Biodiversity impact
evidence: The site development plans will disturb local ecosystems, with likely the greater effects due to the LNG complex and seaport adjacent to the north.

name: Project site area for main facilities
evidence: The overall Project site encompasses approximately 1,050 hectares for main facilities

name: Additional area for offices and services
evidence: an additional 100 hectares allocated for offices and services

name: Area designated for 'New Village' residential development
evidence: A separate area of 292 hectares has been designated for a 'New Village' residential development

name: Estimated construction phase duration
evidence: The construction phase is estimated at 6 years

name: Project category classification
evidence: Greencorp concurs that the Project should be classified as an IFC Category A project

name: Expected environmental impacts containment
value_raw: Limited to project site and immediate vicinity
evidence: The scale and scope of potential environmental and social impacts are limited, with the facility's design incorporating measures to minimize emissions, effluents, and discharges

name: Continuous gas flaring during operations
evidence: Notably, no continuous gas flaring is planned during operations

name: Environmental Basic Law
evidence: The Natarbora Project environmental compliance framework is primarily governed by Timor-Leste's Environment Basic Law, known as Decree Law No. 26 of 2012.

name: Legal Authorization for Environmental Basic Legislation
evidence: This decree in lieu of legislation implements Law No. 3 of 2012 on Legal Authorization for Environmental Basic Legislation (13 January 2012).

name: Category A Projects requirement
value_raw: Environmental Impact Statement and Environmental Management Plan
evidence: Category A Projects require an Environmental Impact Statement and Environmental Management Plan.

name: Category B and C Projects requirement
value_raw: Initial Environmental Examination and Environmental Management Plan
evidence: Categories B and C Projects require an Initial Environmental Examination, 'when applicable,' and an Environmental Management Plan.

name: Sensitive ecosystems classification
evidence: All projects affecting sensitive ecosystems including mangroves are Category A.

name: Ministerial Decision No. 44/2017
value_raw: Regulation on Impact and Benefits Agreement
evidence: Supporting regulations include: Ministerial Decision No. 44/2017 Regulation on Impact and Benefits Agreement (Environmental Impact and Compensation Agreement for Category A Projects).

name: Ministerial Decision No. 45 of 2017
value_raw: Regulation on Statute and Rules of Procedure for Evaluation Committee
evidence: Ministerial Decision No. 45 of 2017 Regulation on Statute and Rules of Procedure for Evaluation Committee for Management of Environmental Assessment Process for Category A Projects.

name: Ministerial Decision No. 46 of 2017
value_raw: Regulation on Detailed Requirements for Screening
evidence: Ministerial Decision No. 46 of 2017 Regulation on Detailed Requirements for Screening, Definition of Scope and Terms of Reference of Environmental Impact Assessment and Environmental Management Plans for Environmental Evaluation.

name: Ministerial Decision No. 47 of 2017
value_raw: Regulation on Procedures for Public Consultation
evidence: Ministerial Decision No. 47 of 2017 Regulation on Procedures for Public Consultation and Requirements during Process of Environmental Assessment.

evidence: Decree-Law No. 5/2011 on Environmental Licensing System (04 February 2011 rev, 8 June 2022).

name: National Environmental Licensing Agency
evidence: Under Decree-Law No. 5/2011, environmental permits for projects in Timor-Leste are under the jurisdiction of the National Environmental Licensing Agency (Agencia Nacional de Licensiamento Ambiental), ANLA.

name: Establishment of ANLA
evidence: ANLA was established by Decree-Law No. 15/2019 as a division of the Secretary of State for Environment.

name: Maximum review period
evidence: Max. 50 days for review

name: Number of Terrestrial and Marine Protected Areas
evidence: The Annex established 46 Terrestrial and Marine Protected Areas.

name: Decree-Law No. for Urban Solid Waste Management System
evidence: Decree-Law No. 2/2017 Approving Urban Solid Waste Management System.

name: Decree-Law No. for Biodiversity Protection and Conservation
evidence: Decree-Law No. 6/2020 Legal Framework for Biodiversity Protection and Conservation in Timor-Leste.

name: Decree-Law No. for National Development Programme for Rural Villages
evidence: Decree-Law No. 08/2013 on National Development Programme for Rural Villages 'Sucos'.

name: Joint Ministerial Order No. for Regulation on Powers of Municipal Authorities
evidence: Joint Ministerial Order No. 43/2017 approving Regulation on Powers of Municipal Authorities and Municipal Administrations in Fields of Water and Sanitation.

name: Adoption of International Finance Corporation Performance Standards
evidence: The Project for developing the Oil Refinery and Petrochemical complex has adopted the International Finance Corporation (IFC) Performance Standards (PS).

name: Adoption of Environmental, Health, and Safety Guidelines
evidence: The Project for developing the Oil Refinery and Petrochemical complex has adopted the Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) Guidelines.

name: Air emission limits for combustion sources
evidence: The Project's air emission limits for exhaust emissions of combustion source emissions with a capacity of up to 50 MWth are to comply with IFC General EHS Guidelines.

name: Health and safety framework
value_raw: IFC EHS Guidelines for Petroleum Refining
evidence: The Project's health and safety framework is primarily governed by the IFC EHS Guidelines for Petroleum Refining.

name: Hazardous area classification standards
value_raw: American Petroleum Institute Recommended Practice (API RP 500)
evidence: Classification of hazardous areas within the site follows American Petroleum Institute Recommended Practice (API RP 500) standards.

name: Equipment certification standards
evidence: specific requirements for explosion-proof equipment certified by RIIS (IEC 60079-11:2023) or other internationally recognized authorities.

name: Climate influence
evidence: The climate of Timor-Leste is predominantly influenced by the Asian tropical monsoon system.

name: Wet season duration
evidence: The wet season, spanning December to May, with peak rainfall typically occurring in January, February, or March.

name: Dry season duration
evidence: The dry season, from June to November, with September and October being the driest months.

name: Temperature variability
evidence: Temperatures are much less variable than rainfall, though obviously also lower at higher elevations than near sea level.

name: Temperature data range
evidence: Figure 4-1 graphs average maximum and minimum monthly temperatures at Natabora from 1958 to 2023.

name: Maximum monthly temperature range
evidence: Average maximum monthly temperatures generally range between 30°C and 32°C.

name: Minimum monthly temperature range
evidence: Average minimums between 20°C and 23°C.

name: Temperature difference
evidence: There is a consistent difference of approximately 8-10°C between the average maximum and minimum monthly temperatures.

name: WHO heat stress threshold
evidence: The World Health Organisation (WHO) heat stress threshold of 35°C lies beyond the range of maximum temperatures ever observed.

name: Minimum annual rainfall
evidence: Recent data show widely variable total annual rainfall can range from a minimum around 740 mm to a maximum up to around 2,300 mm.

name: Maximum annual rainfall
evidence: Recent data show widely variable total annual rainfall can range from a minimum around 740 mm to a maximum up to around 2,300 mm.

name: Average annual rainfall in Natarbora
evidence: Natarbora receives annual average rainfall between 740 to 900 mm.

name: High daily rainfall event
evidence: High daily rainfall events occur relatively infrequently but can reach up to 140 mm.

name: PDSI trend from 1958 to 2023
evidence: Analysis of available climatic data...indicated there is no statistically significant long-term trend in drought severity over the period 1958 to 2023.

name: Period of moderate to severe drought
evidence: There were several periods of drought, notably with the mid-1960s being a period of moderate to severe drought.

name: Extremely wet period
evidence: The early 1970s were an extremely wet period.

name: Increased variability after 2000
evidence: After 2000, data indicate an increased variability compared to earlier years.

name: Dry season wind direction
evidence: "During the dry season in Natarbora (April to November), the wind rose indicates a strong prevailing wind pattern from the south-southeast and south"

name: Wet season wind direction
evidence: "During the wet season in Natarbora (December to March), the wind rose shows a prevailing wind pattern from the west and west-northwest"

name: Wind speed exceeding
evidence: "occasional occurrences of stronger winds, including some unusual instances of winds exceeding 12 m/s"

name: Number of cyclones within 100 km
evidence: "only 8 cyclones passed within 100 km to the site"

name: Area of Timor-Leste
evidence: "covering approximately 15,000 km²"

name: Percentage of land with slope greater than 40%
evidence: "about 44% of the land having a slope greater than 40%"

name: Height of Mount Ramelau
evidence: "with Mount Ramelau being the highest at 2,963 meters"

name: Mean elevation of Timor-Leste
evidence: "The mean elevation is 470 meters"

name: Width of Timor-Leste
evidence: "Timor-Leste's width north to south ranges from 75 to 100 km"

name: Cyclone frequency trend
evidence: "Data suggest that the cyclone frequency has increased slightly but consistently in the project area over the last century"

name: Peak wildfire occurrences
evidence: "Fires reach their peak in October and are largely absent from January to March"

name: Thickness of sediment unit
evidence: The thickness of the unit is reported up to 600 m.

name: Distance to Rib Sahen river
evidence: The Rib Sahen, a major river, flows to the coast less than 3 kilometers southwest of the site.

name: Groundwater reliance during dry season
evidence: Groundwater is a critical resource in Timor-Leste.

name: Agricultural activities in local communities
evidence: Local communities are small and primarily engaged in fishing at artisanal-subsistence scale, as well as (and likely often combined with) farming (mostly maize/corn) and livestock.

name: Transition of project area
value_raw: from natural and semi-natural rural conditions to planned development
evidence: The area is currently undergoing transition from natural and semi-natural rural conditions to planned development.

name: Requirement for vegetation clearing
evidence: Vegetation clearing will be required in places to support the refinery development.

name: Coastal feature at project site
evidence: The coastline at the Project site is dominated by extensive mangrove forests.

name: Ecological services provided by mangroves
value_raw: coastal protection, fisheries support, carbon sequestration
evidence: As mangroves provide crucial ecological services of coastal protection, fisheries support, and carbon sequestration.

name: Project area mangrove contribution
evidence: It counts for about one tenth of the total mangrove areas of Timor Leste.

name: Nearest coral reefs distance
evidence: The nearest coral reefs are about 30 km distant from the site.

name: Discovery of new species
evidence: A recent example highlighting this biodiversity is the discovery of a new species, the Timor Ground Snake (Stegonotus nancuro), identified in 2021.

name: Location of new species discovery
evidence: identified in 2021, approximately 6.5 kilometers south of Natarbora.

name: Endangered species present
evidence: including the Endangered Timor Green-pigeon.

name: Endangered species present
evidence: including the Endangered Wetar Ground Dove.

name: Endangered species present
evidence: including the Critically Endangered Sulphur-crested Cockatoo.

name: Endangered species present
evidence: including the Endangered Large Flying-fox.

name: Endangered species present
evidence: including the Endangered long-tailed Macaque.

name: Endangered species present
evidence: including the Endangered Southeast Asian Box Turtle.

name: Critically Endangered species present
evidence: The Critically Endangered Hawksbill Seaturtle may nest on the sandy beach.

name: Endangered migratory species present
evidence: the Endangered Siberian Sandplover may use the coastal habitat during migration and wintering.

name: Endangered migratory species present
evidence: the Endangered Far Eastern Curlew may use the coastal habitat during migration and wintering.

name: Marine biodiversity
evidence: The Timor Sea, located within the Coral Triangle, is known for its exceptional marine biodiversity.

name: Migratory species in open waters
evidence: The open waters off the southern coast support migratory species, including tuna.

name: Migratory species in open waters
evidence: including cetaceans such as the sperm whale.

name: Project area critical habitat
evidence: the entire project area falls into likely critical habitat area

name: Distance to Aubeon Village
evidence: Aubeon Village is 1.5 kilometers from the plant boundary

name: Distance to Natarbora
evidence: Natarbora, an 'Administrative Post' or district town, is 3.5 kilometers distant

name: Distance to New Village Project
evidence: The 'New Village' (or 'Township') Project residential area is 8.5 kilometers from the plant

name: Number of houses in Aubeon Village
evidence: The number of houses in the Auebon Village is 566

evidence: the average household size nationally has decreased to 4.7 persons

name: Estimated total population in Aubeon Village
evidence: we can estimate the total population in the depicted village is approximately 2,660 people in 2022

name: National population of Timor-Leste

name: Population of Manatuto Municipality
evidence: Manatuto Municipality, in which the site is located, a largely rural area, has a population barely above 50,000

name: Percentage of national population living in Dili
evidence: About a quarter of the national population of about 1.341 million lives in Dili

name: Population of isolated Administrative Post
evidence: the most isolated Administrative Post of the Municipality, with about 12% of the population at just over 6,000 people

name: Percentage of population in isolated Administrative Post
evidence: about 12% of the population at just over 6,000 people

name: Area of mangrove ecosystem restoration
evidence: "managing the restoration of over 580 ha of mangrove ecosystem."

evidence: "the livestock 'fattening' group...had already commenced working on 7 ha of land"

name: Area of land for agriculture group
evidence: "the agriculture group members were expecting a large maize harvest from their 4 ha of land"

name: Area of land for fisheries group
evidence: "the fisheries group were preparing their ponds on more than 1 hectare of land."

name: Percentage of landowners in surveyed villages
evidence: "the study found, of its surveyed respondents in four villages, 83% owned the land they resided on."

name: Percentage of landowners who inherited land
evidence: "Of the landowners, 20% reported inheriting the land."

name: Percentage of landowners who obtained land from Indonesian government
evidence: "17-29% obtained their land from the Indonesian government."

name: Percentage of landowners who obtained land from Timor-Leste government
evidence: "13-17% from the Timor-Leste government."

name: Percentage of farmers hiring tractors for cultivation
evidence: "In the villages studied by Al-Com, 31% of farmers hired tractors to cultivate their land."

name: Percentage of Aubeon farmers planting wet rice
evidence: "About 69% of Aubeon farmers plant some wet (paddy) rice."

name: Percentage of farmers planting only one crop annually
evidence: "mostly (88-90%) only one crop annually."

name: Percentage of landowners selling crops
evidence: "Only 41% of landowners in the study sold any crops."

name: Percentage of farmers using slash-and-burn
evidence: "Slash-and-burn is used by 16% of farmers."

name: Percentage of top crop planted: corn/maize
evidence: "The top three crops planted by respondents were corn/maize (33%)."

name: Percentage of top crop planted: cassava
evidence: "cassava (17%)"

name: Percentage of top crop planted: banana
evidence: "and banana (11%)."

name: Percentage of landowners owning teak trees
evidence: "some 58% of landowners in Aubeon report owning some teak trees."

name: Ethno-linguistic group of respondents
evidence: The respondents in the household survey were mainly of Tetun-Terik ethno-linguistic group (97%).

name: Illiteracy rate among respondents
evidence: Only 25% of respondents were illiterate.

name: Rate of respondents with formal education
evidence: 75% have some formal education.

name: Rate of respondents with primary schooling
evidence: Of these, 33% had primary schooling.

name: Rate of respondents with secondary school or higher
evidence: 28% secondary school or higher.

name: Distance from Suai Supply Base to Natarbora Refinery site
evidence: located 125 km southeast of the Natarbora Refinery site.

name: Year of agreements with community leaders
evidence: A notable achievement in this process occurred in April 2013.

name: Duration of stakeholder engagement documentation
evidence: community disclosure and consultation and overall stakeholder engagement for the South Coast hydrocarbons development date back more than 10 years.

name: Project area includes fishing communities
evidence: The Natarbora Refinery project area includes fishing communities that will require resettlement and livelihood restoration support.

name: Stakeholder engagement strategy alignment
evidence: The project's stakeholder engagement strategy is designed to align with international infrastructure development standards.

name: Stakeholder identification and mapping process
evidence: This process will involve recognizing the diverse range of stakeholders who have an interest in, or will be affected by, the project's activities.

name: Key stakeholders
value_raw: local residents, community leaders, governmental bodies, business entities
evidence: Key stakeholders will include local residents, community leaders, governmental bodies, and business entities.

name: Stakeholder mapping steps
evidence: The initial stakeholder mapping for this Preliminary ESIA considered the following steps: Listing of potential stakeholders, Grouping of stakeholders, Evaluating stakeholders, Prioritizing stakeholders.

name: Stakeholder evaluation criteria
value_raw: level of influence, interest, potential impact
evidence: Evaluating stakeholders based on specific criteria (e.g., their level of influence, interest, and potential impact on the project).

name: Stakeholder prioritization method
value_raw: grid with axes representing power/influence and interest
evidence: Prioritizing stakeholders by position stakeholders on a grid with axes representing their level of power/influence and interest in the project.

name: Project focus
value_raw: Natarbora Refinery and Petrochemical Complex development
evidence: In preparing for Natarbora Refinery and Petrochemical Complex development, disclosure of relevant project information will focus on assisting affected local stakeholders...

name: Community engagement process
evidence: The extent and degree of engagement will adapt in response to concerns raised by the Affected Communities, in a two-way process...

name: Grievance Resolution Mechanism
evidence: ...and the Grievance Resolution Mechanism (GRM, see below).

name: NGO involvement
evidence: Bega Valley Advocates for Timor-Leste focused on supporting local communities

name: NGO focus on biodiversity
evidence: Konservasaun Flora and Fauna (KFF) focused on supporting Biodiversity ('One Child, One Mangrove')

value_raw: Local Agricultural Organisation in the village of Uma-Boco
evidence: Local Agricultural Organisation in the village of Uma-Boco Promoting local agricultural production

name: School involved
evidence: Natarbora Agriculture Technical School

name: Grievance Redress Mechanism (GRM) establishment
evidence: The Company will establish a Grievance Redress Mechanism (GRM) to receive and facilitate resolution of Affected Communities' concerns and grievances about the Project's environmental and social performance.

name: EITI compliance status
evidence: As the first country in the Asia-Pacific region to achieve full EITI compliance

name: Reporting frequency to Affected Communities
evidence: The frequency of these reports will be proportional to the concerns of Affected Communities, but not less than annually.

name: Stakeholder engagement process cost
evidence: readily accessible to them at no cost and without retribution to parties who raise issues or concerns.

name: Reporting standards compliance
evidence: The project demonstrates compliance with international reporting standards, notably as part of Timor-Leste's commitment to the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI).

name: Issues of concern to Affected Communities
value_raw: recruitment and terms of employment, safety or comfort of residents, environmental impacts
evidence: These could include recruitment and terms of employment of residents for temporary, short-term, and permanent employment with the Refinery Project. These could also include issues with Project operations affecting the safety or comfort of residents, or environmental impacts impinging on natural resources of importance to the livelihoods of local residents.

name: GHG emissions reporting threshold
evidence: "projects are required to manage and report their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions if the project emits more than 25,000 metric tons of CO 2 -equivalent per year"

name: Groundwater extraction rate
evidence: The significance of the groundwater extraction rate of 280 liters per second (l/s) as proposed in this Project depends on the capacity and sustainability of the local aquifer system.

name: Sea water cooling system duty load
evidence: The sea water cooling system duty load is 620 MW.

name: Sea water requirement for cooling system
evidence: ...requiring up to 107,000 cubic meters per hour (m3/hr or TPH) of water.

name: Maximum sea water temperature rise
evidence: ...with a maximum sea water temperature rise of 5°C within the mixing zone.

name: Typical yield of industrial deep wells
evidence: The typical yield of industrial deep wells varies widely, depending on geological characteristics of the aquifer, the depth of the well, and local hydrogeological conditions, and can range from 5 to 50 liters per second (l/s).

name: Water supply system type
evidence: A dual water supply system is planned, utilizing both freshwater and seawater.

name: Freshwater availability during dry season
evidence: However, on the south coast of Timor-Leste, freshwater availability during the dry season is limited due reduced rainfall.

evidence: Designation of Aubeon Lagoon (and possibly a more extensive area) as Critical Habitat is indicated.

name: Population concentration in Dili
evidence: Dili, which itself contains a quarter of the population.

name: Population percentage in Manatuto
evidence: Manatuto, where the project is located, comprises less than 2% of the population.

name: Travel time from Aubeon to Dili
evidence: Aubeon, located a five-hour drive from Dili.

name: Employment impact focus
value_raw: local employment, business development, macroeconomic effects
evidence: Analysis suggests potential impacts across multiple economic sectors, with a focus on local employment, business development, and macroeconomic effects.

name: Economic modeling approaches used
value_raw: input-output (I-O) multipliers and computable general equilibrium (CGE) modeling
evidence: Economic modeling approaches such as input-output (I-O) multipliers and computable general equilibrium (CGE) modeling have been employed.

name: Challenges for local residents
evidence: This demographic imbalance suggests local residents may face challenges competing for project-related jobs, particularly in construction and operations.

name: Employment opportunities for residents
evidence: "Some residents may secure employment within the project, though not in higher-paying roles."

name: Economic activity during construction
evidence: "While increased economic activity during refinery construction and operation may spur local business development..."

name: Youthful labor force
evidence: "the country and region are characterized by a large, youthful labor force."

name: Economic inequalities
evidence: "it cannot employ everyone, potentially exacerbating perceived economic inequalities."

name: Stakeholder engagement focus
evidence: "Baseline social assessments and stakeholder engagement should prioritize dialogue with community leaders..."

name: Cultural significance
value_raw: Sacred sites and culturally significant areas
evidence: "Particular attention should be given to sacred sites and culturally significant areas..."

name: Cumulative impact analysis
evidence: "Cumulative impact analysis will only be possible with a better understanding of the closely associated LNG and Seaport (Marine Facility) developments..."

name: Sea level rise rate
evidence: Initial assessments indicate that sea levels near Timor-Leste have been rising at approximately 9 mm per year since 1993

name: Projected sea level rise by 2030
evidence: Projections under a very high emissions scenario estimate a rise of 9-18 cm by 2030

name: Projected sea level rise by 2100
evidence: Projections under a very high emissions scenario estimate potentially more than 1 meter by 2100

name: Groundwater scarcity
evidence: Groundwater also constitutes an important VEC due to the prevailing water scarcity during the dry season

name: Increased rainfall intensity
evidence: Long-term projections suggest that there will likely be an uptick in extreme rainfall events

name: Coastal flooding risk
evidence: This shift is expected to intensify the existing high-risk of coastal flooding in the site region

name: Saltwater intrusion
evidence: Sea level rise will increase saltwater intrusion into coastal aquifers

name: Freshwater demand from new development
evidence: This scarcity, coupled with the substantial freshwater demand anticipated from the new development

name: Tail Gas sulfur emissions
evidence: Tail Gas sulfur emissions from this recovery unit will be below 4 kg SO2/day.

name: Plant availability
evidence: The financial model assumes non-turnaround year plant availability above 96%.

name: Distance from Aubeon Village to flare
evidence: located at distances approximately 3 km from Aubeon Village.

name: Distance from Natarbora to flare
evidence: located at distances approximately 3.5 km from Natarbora.

name: Distance from New Village housing complex to flare
evidence: located at distances approximately 9 km from the New Village housing complex.

name: Distance from plant's office to nearest flare
evidence: The nearest flare is about 1 km from the plant's office and services area.

name: Waste production estimate
evidence: with the types and amounts (likely a few tonnes per year) being estimated in design planning.

name: Waste management compliance
evidence: All hazardous wastes will be managed in compliance with international industry standards.

name: Project area buffer zone
evidence: "Defining ecological areas for detailed assessment, starting within the boundary of the project's industrial facilities and proposed New Village housing complex, and extending outward to at least a 1-km buffer."

name: IUCN Critically Endangered species assessment
evidence: "Conducting field surveys for the presence of IUCN Critically Endangered (CR), Endangered (EN), and Vulnerable species within the project area and its buffers."

name: IUCN Endangered species assessment
evidence: "Conducting field surveys for the presence of IUCN Critically Endangered (CR), Endangered (EN), and Vulnerable species within the project area and its buffers."

name: IUCN Vulnerable species assessment
evidence: "Conducting field surveys for the presence of IUCN Critically Endangered (CR), Endangered (EN), and Vulnerable species within the project area and its buffers."

name: Biodiversity Offset Plan initiation
evidence: "Initiating Biodiversity Offset Plan (BOP) studies, beginning with reconnaissance and detailed studies of remote potential offset sites."

name: Climate Change Risk Assessment integration
evidence: "Incorporating the region's biodiversity vulnerability to climate change into the Project Climate Change Risk Assessment to develop adaptive strategies."

name: Long-term management and monitoring program
evidence: "The outcome of these tasks is the establishment of a long-term management and monitoring program as a core component of the ESMP."

name: Project focus
evidence: The Natarbora Refinery and Petrochemical Complex incorporates several socioeconomic management measures focused on maximizing benefits for the people of Timor-Leste while mitigating potential risks.

name: Employment generation
evidence: Key management priorities include local employment generation, business development opportunities, and infrastructure enhancement.

name: Economic activity stimulation
evidence: It is expected stimulation of higher levels of economic activity will assist primary sector workers.

name: Targeted training initiatives
value_raw: targeted training and capacity building initiatives
evidence: The Project early documents had ambitious aims to integrate unskilled and low-skilled workers from the subsistence economy into the formal sector, supported by targeted training and capacity building initiatives.

name: Management measures focus
evidence: Management measures emphasize the need for balanced development, addressing both immediate project impacts and longer-term socioeconomic transformation.

name: Grievance resolution
evidence: Grievances must be resolved quickly and equitably, even at the risk of delaying critical path items.

name: Cultural dynamics importance
value_raw: long-established knowledge of local cultural dynamics
evidence: This is best dealt with by having long-established knowledge of the local cultural dynamics and structures of authority and influence.

name: Residual impacts
value_raw: potential disruptions to local community livelihoods
evidence: The key residual impacts involve potential disruptions to local community livelihoods, including farming, herding, and fishing.

name: Cumulative impacts evaluation
evidence: The proposed development of the LNG facility and seaport markedly amplifies these concerns, necessitating a comprehensive evaluation of cumulative impacts.

name: Project impact on local communities
evidence: The refinery's isolated impact on the village center and southern Aubeon Mangrove Lagoon is significant yet manageable

name: Anticipated ecological changes
evidence: The anticipated conversion of a lagoon segment into a harbor will result in substantial ecological changes

name: Construction interdependency
evidence: The simultaneous construction of the refinery, LNG plant, and port is essential, given their interdependency

name: Workforce requirement
evidence: This requires a larger workforce and extended construction timeline

name: Economic opportunities in Timor-Leste
value_raw: substantial opportunities for economic and social progress
evidence: The project and broader South Coast development offer substantial opportunities for economic and social progress in Timor-Leste

name: GDP impact
evidence: aiming to boost national GDP, export earnings, and government revenues

name: Job creation
evidence: targeting macroeconomic growth alongside local community development through job creation

name: Construction phase challenge
evidence: The construction phase poses a significant disruptive challenge

name: Lifecycle cost reduction strategy
evidence: converting temporary structures for community use can lower overall lifecycle costs

name: Project alternatives considered
value_raw: no action option, technology alternatives, siting alternatives
evidence: Project alternatives considered in this Chapter are no action option, technology alternatives, and siting alternatives.

name: Distance between key locations
evidence: The site selection process historically concentrated on two key locations along TimorLeste's southern coast: the Natarbora and Beaço sites, approximately 60 kilometers apart.

name: Environmental feasibility of the project
evidence: The preliminary assessment indicates that the project is environmentally feasible, contingent upon the implementation of recommended management and mitigation strategies.

name: Importance of further environmental studies
evidence: Achieving success will depend significantly on the outcomes of further environmental studies, as outlined in the following recommendations.

name: Baseline Surveys Requirement
evidence: Extensive biological surveys are necessary to more accurately understand the presence and distribution of sensitive wildlife within the project area.

name: Critical Habitat Determination
evidence: Additional efforts are required to ascertain the presence of critical habitats and defining their characteristics.

name: Intensive Field Research Requirement
evidence: Intensive field research is required to assess endangered, threatened, exploited, and economically significant terrestrial and aquatic species both in the region and at the project site.

name: Community Concern on Species
evidence: Local villagers have expressed concern about the attention given to certain species that have become primary sources of supplemental income through hunting and the live-capture trade.

name: Economic Contribution of Species
evidence: ...which significantly contributes to essential expenses like paying school fees.

name: Biodiversity Action Plan Requirement
evidence: Development must be accompanied by a comprehensive Biodiversity Action/Management Plan to ensure proactive management and protection of local ecosystems.

name: Biodiversity Offsets Recommendation
evidence: It is advisable to identify and implement biodiversity offsets.

name: Stakeholder Engagement Importance
evidence: Further community consultation is essential to address a broad range of concerns spanning environmental, gender, socioeconomic, and cultural issues.

name: Community Awareness of Job Opportunities
value_raw: Awareness of potential job filling by outsiders
evidence: They are acutely aware of the potential for most project jobs to be filled by individuals from outside the district, or even by foreigners.

name: Gap in Community Understanding
value_raw: Significant gap in understanding environmental impacts
evidence: Additionally, there is a significant gap in the community's understanding of the environmental impacts.

name: Frequency of Community Consultations
evidence: To date, community consultation efforts have been infrequent and limited.

name: Project Information Dissemination
value_raw: Project information largely among elites in Dili
evidence: ...with project information largely disseminated among elites in Dili.

name: Future Consultation Priorities
value_raw: Prioritize capturing genuine attitudes and opinions
evidence: Future consultations should prioritize capturing the genuine attitudes and opinions of local residents.

name: Distance to Church
evidence: Church 3 to 4 kilometers from Aubeon settlement

name: Distance to Clinic
evidence: Clinic about 3 kilometers from Aubeon settlement

name: Types of Vegetables
value_raw: corn, red beans, green beans, peanuts, long beans, potatoes, mustard greens, carrots, cassava leaves, pumpkin
evidence: Vegetables --corn, red beans, green beans, peanuts, long beans, potatoes, mustard greens, carrots, cassava leaves, pumpkin.

name: Types of Fruits
value_raw: banana, coconut, mango, pineapple, orange, jackfruit, papaya
evidence: Fruits --banana, coconut, mango, pineapple, orange, jackfruit and papaya.

name: Development Programs
value_raw: teak planting and mangrove protection programs
evidence: Teak planting and mangrove protection programs
